standard_metadata.standard_description: Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane, and interpret coordinate values of points in the context of the situation.

question.content: **Use the following coordinate plane to write the ordered pair for each point.**       Point | Ordered pair - | -  $\greenD{A}$ | $($  ,  $)$ $\purpleC{B}$| $($  ,  $)$ $\blueD{C}$| $($  ,  $)$

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. Point A is 5 units to the right and 6 units up from the origin. Point B is 2 units up from the origin on the y-axis. Point C is 4 units to the right and 1 unit up from the origin.

hints.content: The **ordered pair** of a point tells us how to get to it from the origin.  [[☃ image 2]]  $\begin{array}{cc} (\goldE{\text{distance right}},& \maroonD{\text{distance up}})\\ \swarrow&\searrow\\ \goldE{x\text{-coordinate}}&\maroonD{y\text{-coordinate}} \end{array}$  We are asked to find the $\goldE{x\text{-coordinate}}$ and $\maroonD{y\text{-coordinate}}$.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from 1 to 4 from the origin in both the x and y-axis. The point the x and y-axis intersect is labeled origin.

hints.content: To get to point $\greenD{A}$ from the origin, we move right to $\goldE{5}$ and up to $\maroonD{6}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  So, the ordered pair for point $\greenD{A}$ is $(\goldE5,\maroonD6)$.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A brown arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 5. A red arrow moves up 6 units from the 5 ton the x-axis o align with 6 on the y-axis. Point A is plotted at the end of the red arrow.

hints.content: To get to point $\purpleD{B}$ from the origin , we move right $\goldE{0}$ and up to $\maroonD{2}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  So, the ordered pair for point $\purpleD{B}$ is $(\goldE0,\maroonD2)$.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A red arrow moves up along the y-axis from the origin to the 2. Point B is plotted at the end of the red arrow.

hints.content: To get to point $\blueD{C}$ from the origin, we move right to $\goldE{4}$ and up to $\maroonD{1}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  So, the ordered pair for point $\blueD{C}$ is $(\goldE4,\maroonD1)$.

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A brown arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 4. A red arrow moves up 1 unit from the 4 ton the x-axis o align with the 1 on the y-axis. Point C is plotted at the end of the red arrow.

hints.content: Point | Ordered pair - | -  $\greenD{A}$ | $(\goldE5,\maroonD6)$ $\purpleD{B}$| $(\goldE0,\maroonD2)$ $\blueD{C}$| $(\goldE4,\maroonD1)$

hints.content: To get to point $\purpleD{B}$ from the origin , we move right $\goldE{3}$ and up to $\maroonD{3}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  So, the ordered pair for point $\purpleD{B}$ is $(\goldE3,\maroonD3)$.

question.content: **Which ordered pair is *not* graphed below?**

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the X-axis and the Y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. From left to right the first plot point is 2 units up from the origin on the Y-axis. The second plot point is 2 units to the right of and 4 units up from the origin. The last plot point is 4 units to the right of the origin on the X-axis.

hints.content: The **ordered pair** of a point tells us how to get to it from the origin.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{array}{cc} (\goldE{\text{distance right}},& \maroonD{\text{distance up}})\\ \swarrow&\searrow\\ \goldE{x\text{-coordinate}}&\maroonD{y\text{-coordinate}} \end{array}$

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled from 1 to 4 from the origin in both the x and y-axis. The point the x and y-axis intersect is labeled origin.

hints.content: Let's label the graphed points.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the X-axis and the Y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. From left to right the first plot point represents the ordered pair (0,2). The second plot represents the ordered pair (2,4). The third plot point represents the ordered pair (4,0).

hints.content: $\redD{(4,2)}$ was not graphed.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 to 6 on the X-axis and the Y-axis. Four plot points are on different parts of the grid. From left to right the first plot point represents the ordered pair (0,2). The second plot point represents the ordered pair (2,4). The third plot point represents the ordered pair (4,2). The last plot point represents the ordered pair (4,0).
